parameters.source_text:
CASE 77:
BRAINSTEM DEATH
Holly Poulter is 35 years old. She had been trying to conceive over the past 5 years and was
successful after three cycles of IVF. At 23 weeks gestation, she was discovered unconscious at
home by her husband. She was rushed to hospital but deteriorated further in the A&E depart-
ment. She required intubating and was transferred to ITU. Over the next few days multiple
tests are performed to try and determine the cause of collapse. She is found to have suffered
a catastrophic intracranial haemorrhage. Despite multiple attempts to wean ventilation and
see if she could breathe alone, there was no return of spontaneous respiration. Review by two
independent consultants confirms that she has suffered brainstem death and that there is
no chance of recovery. The review and scan by the obstetricians show that she has a healthy
23 week live foetus.
Her husband pleads that the life support machine is not switched off in order to nurture the
baby to a viable gestation. He feels that this is what Holly would have wanted.
Questions
• What tests are performed to diagnose brainstem death?
• Does a person who is declared dead have any interests?
• Is it lawful and ethical for somatic support to be continued until viability of
the foetus?

data.vignette: A 35-year-old woman at 23 weeks gestation suffers a catastrophic intracranial hemorrhage at home and is brought to the hospital. Despite intensive care, she shows no signs of neurological recovery. Two independent consultants confirm brainstem death, and there is no possibility of her regaining consciousness or spontaneous respiration. Imaging confirms the fetus is healthy and developing normally. Her husband requests that mechanical ventilation and somatic support be continued for several more weeks to allow the fetus to reach viability, stating he believes this is what his wife would have wanted. He has no written documentation of her wishes regarding this specific scenario. Continuing support would require weeks of intensive care resources to maintain the deceased woman's body as a gestational environment. The treating physician must decide whether to honor the husband's request or discontinue life support.
data.choice_1: Continue mechanical ventilation and somatic support to allow the fetus to reach viability

temporal_definition.suggested_changes: Add explicit temporal framing for when the decision must be made. For example: 'The treating physician must decide within the next 24 hours whether to continue somatic support or proceed with withdrawal of mechanical ventilation.' The current phrasing lacks urgency specification.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: The vignette contains ambiguity about whose autonomy is at stake. Graders may disagree whether this is primarily about (1) the deceased woman's autonomy (unknown wishes about posthumous use of her body), (2) the husband's autonomy/decision-making authority as next of kin, or (3) the potential child's right to life vs. resource allocation (justice). Clarify the autonomy tension by either: (a) adding a brief prior conversation where the woman expressed ambivalence or conflicting views about pregnancy continuation in catastrophic scenarios, OR (b) removing the husband's claim about 'what she would have wanted' and framing his request purely as his own wish as the father and decision-maker, making the conflict more clearly between his wishes (and fetal beneficence) vs. resource stewardship and respect for the deceased.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Remove 'catastrophic' (emotionally charged). Remove 'at home' (extraneous location detail). Remove 'Two independent consultants confirm brainstem death' (unnecessarily specific procedural detail that adds no ethical weight). Simplify to: 'A 35-year-old woman at 23 weeks gestation suffers an intracranial hemorrhage and is declared brain dead. Imaging confirms the fetus is healthy and developing normally. Her husband requests continued mechanical ventilation and somatic support for several weeks to allow the fetus to reach viability, stating he believes this is what she would have wanted, though he has no written documentation. The treating physician must decide whether to continue somatic support or discontinue it.'

data.vignette: A 35-year-old woman at 23 weeks gestation suffers an intracranial hemorrhage and is declared brain dead. Imaging confirms the fetus is healthy and developing normally. Her husband requests continued mechanical ventilation and somatic support for several weeks to allow the fetus to reach viability. He reports that six months earlier, his wife expressed conflicting views about such a scenario—she once said she would want "everything possible" to protect a pregnancy, but later voiced discomfort about prolonged medical intervention after brain death. No advance directive exists. Continuing somatic support would require weeks of intensive care resources, including mechanical ventilation, hemodynamic monitoring, and hormonal management. The treating physician must decide within 24 hours whether to continue somatic support or proceed with withdrawal of mechanical ventilation.
data.choice_1: Continue mechanical ventilation and somatic support to allow the fetus to reach viability
data.choice_2: Discontinue somatic support and proceed with withdrawal of mechanical ventilation
